Chapter 2, Section 4: Having already explained homogeneity and its absence,
among the eighteen elements, how many are to be eliminated by seeing, how many are to be eliminated by cultivation, and how many are not to be eliminated?
Verse:
Fifteen are only eliminated by cultivation, the last three elements are of three kinds,
Uncontaminated ones are not born from the six, form is not eliminated by seeing.
Treatise:
The fifteen are the ten form elements and the five consciousness elements.
Only eliminated by cultivation means these fifteen elements are only eliminated by cultivation.
The last three elements are the mind element, the dharma element, and the mental consciousness element, because they are the last of the six triads.

The three that are common to all are the eighty-eight propensities, the dharmas associated with them, and the various acquisitions of these propensities and dharmas, as well as the dharmas that are born with them, etc. All of these are eliminated by the path of insight. The remaining impure dharmas are eliminated by the path of cultivation. All pure dharmas are not eliminated.
In order to determine this matter, the text says again, NOT DEFILING.
The form dharmas born of the six sense organs are definitely not eliminated by insight.
The term NOT DEFILING refers to impure good and nondetermined indeterminate dharmas.
The term BORN OF THE SIX is the sixth, which is the sense center of thought.
Dharmas born differently from this are called NOT BORN OF THE SIX.
This means that they are born from the five sense organs, such as the eye, and refer to the five consciousnesses, etc.
The term FORM refers to impure defiled and undefiled form.
These three classes are definitely not eliminated by insight.

First, as for the dharmas that are not defiling and the dharmas of form that are not eliminated by insight, this is because when the passions that have them as objects are finally eliminated, they are then said to be eliminated.
What is the meaning of ELIMINATION?
In brief, there are two kinds:
The first is the severing of bonds, and the second is the severing of objects.
As for the severing of bonds, a scripture says:
One truly knows that one has no internal eye bonds.
As for the severing of objects, a scripture says:
If you bhiká¹£us can eliminate craving for the eye, then the eye is said to be permanently eliminated.
The great abhidharma masters established two kinds of severing based on those [two types of severing mentioned in the scriptures]:
the first is natural severing, and the second is objective severing.
When the antidote to a dharma that is a bond and a single fruit, etc. arises, one attains severing with regard to it, called natural severing.
Due to the severing of that [bond], one attains disjunction with regard to the objective realm, but one does not necessarily attain non-accomplishment with regard to it, called objective severing.

In this context, all uncontaminated and defiled formless [aggregates], defiled form, and the dharmas such as birth that arise with them, are bound by the fetters that are eliminated by seeing and cultivation. When the fetters are gradually eliminated, at the time of the arising of the disjunction [achievements] on the individual natures of each category, those fetters and one fruit and so forth are all called already eliminated.

The disjunction achievements on the uncontaminated formless [aggregates], defiled form, and the dharmas such as birth that arise with them, have not yet arisen at that time, and are not yet called eliminated, because those dharmas are only eliminated by the final uninterrupted paths of each stage, and the path of seeing cannot gradually eliminate desire by distinguishing the stages.
How can one eliminate the uncontaminated and other dharmas, but not the dharmas born of the six [sense bases] and those eliminated by seeing?
Because they revolve externally, taking form and so forth as objects.
Thus the eliminated by seeing and so forth have been explained.
Among the eighteen elements, how many are views and how many are not views?
In verse it is said:
One part of the eye element and the dharma element are said to be the eight kinds of seeing.
The wisdom that arises together with the five consciousnesses is not seeing, because it does not judge.
The eye sees the same kind of form, not the consciousness, because it is the cause of seeing.
Because the classes of consciousness are not different, and because it does not observe obstructed form.
The treatise says:
The entire eye is seeing. One part of the dharma element is the eight kinds of seeing, and the rest are not seeing.
What are the eight?
They are the five defiled views such as the view of the self, worldly right views, the right views of those still learning, and the right views of those beyond learning.
Among the dharma element, these eight are seeing.
The rest of the dharma element and the other sixteen are all not seeing.
Among all dharmas, only two dharmas are the substance of seeing. Among material dharmas, only the eye is seeing. Among non-material dharmas, the aspect of wisdom that is clear and sharp,
investigating and judging the objects that arise internally is seeing, and not the others.

The eye faculty has already been explained above, because it is commonly understood in the world, because its nature is that of illumination, because it is in opposition to darkness, and because its function is that of clear vision. Therefore, it is said that the eye sees.
The five defiled views will be explained in the chapter on latent afflictions.

Correct worldly views refer to wholesome and contaminated supreme faculties associated with the mental consciousness.ğŸ”½Correct views of those still learning refer to all uncontaminated wisdom in the body of those still learning.
Correct views of those no longer learning refer to the uncontaminated wisdom of those who have attained final liberation in the body of those no longer learning.
The word correct view includes all three types.

The reason for distinguishing them into three is to show the differences between the views of ordinary beings, those still learning, and those no longer learning, and also to show that they arise through gradual practice.
These various views can be divided into five general categories:
1. The indeterminate class, 2. The defiled class, 3. The wholesome and contaminated class, 4. The class of those still learning, and 5. The class of those no longer learning.
In the indeterminate class, the eye faculty is seeing, but the ear and other faculties, as well as all indeterminate wisdom, etc., are not seeing.

In the defiled class, the five views are seeing, but the other defiled wisdoms are not seeing, namely, the wisdoms associated with craving, hatred, pride, unique ignorance, and doubt, and the other defiled dharmas are also not seeing.
In the class of learners, there is no wisdom that is not seeing, but the rest are not seeing.
In the class of post-learners, the knowledge of elimination and non-arising, as well as the rest that are not seeing, and the other post-learner wisdoms are all seeing.
In the class of wholesome and contaminated dharmas, only the wholesome wisdom associated with mental consciousness is seeing, the rest are not seeing.

Other masters say that the wholesome and contaminated wisdom associated with mental consciousness is also not seeing, namely, the wisdom elicited by the five sense consciousnesses, the wisdom that gives rise to intimation, and the wisdom at the moment of death.
Also, in this class of wholesome and contaminated dharmas, the wisdom co-arising with the five sense consciousnesses is also not seeing.
Why are the above-mentioned kinds of discernment not views?
Because they do not judge and determine.

Only the characteristics of discernment mentioned above are views, that is, discernment that is clear and sharp in its mode of activity among the formless mental activities, that judges and determines its object, and that evolves internally through the six sense organs. The other mental activities are not views. Only discernment with these characteristics can judge and determine, because it evolves in a state of thorough consideration of its object.
The discernment that is excluded above is not able to thoroughly consider and judge and determine its object, and therefore it is not a view.
The term judge and determine means that, with regard to an object, one first thoroughly considers it and then finally decides on it.
The discernment associated with the five consciousnesses is not able to thoroughly know an object that has already been perceived.
It evolves in a state of seeking and judging what is proper and improper, and for that reason it is called judging and determining.
Discernment in the sixth or mental consciousness is able to thoroughly consider an object, decide on it, and therefore can be called seeing.
The five consciousnesses are devoid of discrimination and, therefore, the discernment associated with them is not capable of this and, therefore, is not called seeing.
If this is so, then since the eye does not have this characteristic, it should not be called seeing.

Didn't we say earlier that it is called seeing because it is commonly understood as such, because it has the nature of illumination, because it is opposed to darkness, and because its function is clear and sharp?
A scripture also says:
The eye sees various forms, therefore it is said that the eye faculty can see various forms.
If the eye sees, why doesn't it simultaneously obtain all objects?
There is no such fault, because it is admitted that a small part of the eye can see forms.
What is this small part?
It refers to the homogeneous eye, the homogeneous eye faculty.
As explained before, it becomes homogeneous when it is sustained by consciousness.
Not all faculties simultaneously sustain their own consciousnesses, therefore there is no fault in this.
If this is so, then the consciousness that depends on it should be seeing, not the eye, because it is only when eye consciousness arises that there can be seeing.
This is not so, because the eye consciousness is powerfully sustained and its superior function arises.
It is like fire arising with superior function depending on the power of firewood.

If you see the function of seeing as a dharma produced by consciousness, then this seeing of the function of seeing should arise apart from the eye, because consciousness nourishes and benefits the simultaneously born primary elements, causing the superior faculty to arise that is able to see various forms. Therefore, you should not say that the consciousness that is the support is seeing.
What wise person would make such a statement?
All causes and conditions that are able to produce discrimination, such as this discrimination, are those causes and conditions.
Consciousness is the cause of seeing, therefore it is not the substance of seeing.

Moreover, the substance of eye consciousness is no different from the consciousnesses of the ear, etc., therefore it definitely is not the substance of seeing. What difference is there between eye consciousness and the consciousnesses of the ear, etc., that it alone is called seeing? Therefore, the assertion that consciousness is seeing is definitely unreasonable.
Moreover, there are other masters who establish by a separate principle that eye consciousness definitely is not seeing, saying that it is unable to see obstructed form.

It is a fact of direct perception that forms obstructed by walls and so on are not seen. If consciousness sees, then since consciousness is unimpeded, it should see forms obstructed by walls and so on. Therefore the meaning of the eye and so on apprehending objects is established, that is, the eye sees, the ear hears, the nose smells, the tongue tastes, and the body senses.
The general characteristics of the function of seeing have been established in this way. Now we must consider the specific characteristics of the function of seeing.
Is it one eye that sees the forms that are seen, or are it both eyes that see?
If one of the two eyes is closed or if one eye is damaged, the other eye cannot see. Therefore we know that one eye can also see forms.
If the two eyes are undamaged and open, then both eyes see forms simultaneously.
The meaning of one eye seeing forms is evident and easily established, but the meaning of both seeing is difficult to establish, and therefore we must explain it.
A verse says:
Sometimes both eyes see forms simultaneously, because seeing is clear.
The treatise says:
Sometimes both eyes can see forms simultaneously. What is the definite knowledge of this?
Because the seeing is clear.
When one eye is closed, the seeing is not clear, but when both eyes are open, the seeing of that form is clear.
If the two eyes see sequentially, then even when both eyes are open, there would only be one seeing.
Just as when one eye is closed, the seeing of form is unclear, it would be the same when both eyes are open.
Just as when both eyes are open, the seeing of form is clear, it would be the same when one eye is closed.
Since it is not so, one should know that sometimes both eyes see together, because the nature of seeing is unitary.
Even if there were a hundred thousand eyes, only one consciousness would arise, let alone only two.
When the eyes and other faculties directly apprehend their objects, do they do so by reaching them or not?
Why does doubt arise about this?
Because it is seen that there are two statements in the scriptures.
As the World-Honored One said:
Sentient beings are constrained by the eyes and forms, whether loved or not loved.
If they do not reach each other, the meaning of constraint is established.
Moreover, the World-Honored One said:
They observe sentient beings with the divine eye, and so on, whether far or near.
It is not possible to establish far and near for objects that have arrived.
Because of these two statements, doubts arise again.

The meaning of the sense faculties and objects coming into contact is not fixed. If contact is called coming into contact based on the function of reaching the object, then all sense faculties only take objects that have arrived.
If it is called coming into contact based on the uninterrupted nature of the substance,
The verse says:
The objects of the eye, ear, and mind faculties are not contacted. The three are in opposition.
The treatise says:
The eye, ear, and mind faculties take non-contacted objects. The eye simultaneously takes distant and near objects.
Also, because it cannot take objects that are adjacent, and also because it can take forms obstructed by crystal and so on, and also because there is doubt about what is seen.
Also, because the eye has no way to reach distant objects, it takes non-contacted objects.
The ear faculty also only takes non-contacted objects, because sounds in the four directions, far and near, can be understood.
Also, it takes distant and nearby sounds, whether understood or not. Also, it takes distant and nearby sounds, whether doubtful or certain.
The mental faculty only takes non-contiguous objects, because it does not take simultaneous dharmas as objects, and because it is formless and cannot reach other places.
Therefore, the mental faculty takes non-contiguous objects.
The other three faculties, nose, tongue, and body, are the opposite of the above. They only take contiguous objects.
Aren't the atoms mutually non-contacting?
If the atoms were to contact each other with their entire bodies, there would be the fault of real entities interpenetrating. If they contacted each other with a part, they would have parts.
How do the nose, etc., take contiguous objects?
Now, the meaning of contiguous is that the object and faculty arise in close proximity, and only then can they take each other as objects.
Based on this principle, it is said that the nose, tongue, and body only take contiguous objects.

For example, when the eyelids and a stick reach the eye, the eye cannot see them. The eyelids and so on do not have to touch the eye faculty in order to be called reached. They are simply called reached when they arise in close proximity to the faculty.
Because it cannot see such reached forms, it is said that the eye faculty takes non-reached objects.

Just as the eye faculty and so on take non-reached objects, but cannot take extremely distant objects, the nose and so on are also like this. Although they take reached objects, they cannot take extremely close objects. They are simply due to smells and so on arising in close proximity to the faculty.
Therefore it is said without error that the three faculties take reached objects. The faculties of nose, smell, and so on are not mutually contacting ultimate atoms, because they are not contacted.
And because they are obstructive resistance, contact would be erroneous.
In order to clarify this meaning, one should further investigate.
If someone raises an objection, saying:
If the ultimate atoms do not mutually contact each other, how can sound be produced by striking them?
How can this be the same as the argument of the owl's chicks, which requires the combination of qualities to produce sound?
However, when things combine, the principle is not established, so the combination of qualities should not be accepted as producing sound.
If so, how can sound be produced?

In this true and holy teaching, the connection of names with combination and separation is only based on the primary elements. This is because when the two superior primary elements combine or separate, they obtain that name.
At this stage, the primary elements are the cause for the production of sound, and only the sound produced together with them is the object of the ears.
What fault is there in this?
They do not accept it, and I do not accept it either.
There are also reasons, namely, since the ultimate atoms do not touch each other, how can the combination of the primary elements of this and that be established?
When they are born in close proximity, they are called combined. How can it be that they must touch each other in order to be called combined?
Moreover, you should not hesitate over this meaning, that the primary elements of this and that definitely do not touch each other.
Why is this?
Because it is that which is touched, not that which touches.

Among the form aggregates, only the element of touch is called that which is touched, and only the body faculty is called that which touches. The meaning of external touch should not be further considered.

If it is said that that which is touched can also touch, then it should be admitted that the body faculty is also that which is touched. Then the object and the possessor of the object would be confused and disordered.
If it is said that there is no fault of confusion and disorder between these two, because the object and the support of body consciousness are different,
how can this not lead to confusion and disorder?ğŸ”½If the body faculty is also that which is touched, why does it not become the object of body consciousness?
If it is admitted that the element of touch can also touch, why does it not become the support of body consciousness?
Therefore, the principle that the primary elements of the two do not definitely touch each other is extremely well established.
If that is so, how can the body faculty and the element of touch be able to touch each other and still be established as that which is touched?
Because the atoms of the faculty and the object are born in close proximity.

Arenâ€™t all the nose, tongue, and body faculties without distinction all able to take objects that reach them? Then the faculty of touch would be common to the nose and tongue faculties, and the objects of touch would also be shared by odors and tastes.
This objection is unreasonable, because even though the three are similar in being proximate, there are distinctions among them.

Also, smoothness, roughness, etc., are names for objects of touch that are commonly produced in the world. In relation to the body faculty, they are called objects of touch. Therefore there is no error.
The extensive discernment of the rest of this issue is like that in the Tattvasiddhi.
Now we should investigate the faculties such as the eyes. Do they only grasp objects of equal size, like a wheel of fire that appears to be a large mountain, because they move quickly?
Or do they grasp objects of equal size and unequal size in relation to themselves?
The verse says:
You should know that the three faculties of nose, etc., only grasp objects of equal size.
The treatise says:ğŸ”½The three faculties of nose, tongue, and body only grasp objects of equal size.
This is because the three faculties of nose, tongue, and body are not able to grasp objects that are larger than they are.

The quantity of atoms of nose, tongue, and body faculties is the same as the quantity of atoms of odor, taste, and tactile objects, because the nose, tongue, and body consciousnesses arise from the union of faculties and objects of equal quantity.
Why is it said that the three faculties of nose, tongue, and body only take objects of equal quantity, when sometimes the atoms of the three faculties are unable to pervade the odors, etc.?

Because the atoms of the three faculties of nose, tongue, and body are unable to take objects of greater quantity than the atoms of odor, etc., it is said that they only take objects of equal quantity.

It is not that there are no atoms of the three faculties that are also able to take a small part of the three objects. According to the quantity of atoms of the objects, the faculties are few or many, and that many atoms of the faculties are able to give rise to function.

The eye and ear are not fixed. Sometimes the eye takes a small object, like seeing the tip of a hair. Sometimes it takes a large object, like temporarily opening the eyes and seeing large mountains, etc. Sometimes it takes an object of equal quantity, like seeing grapes, wild jujube fruits, etc.
The ear faculty also takes objects of different quantities, such as the sounds of mosquitoes, thunder, and lutes.
The mind has no material obstruction and cannot be distinguished in terms of differences in size and shape.
The verse says one should know in order to encourage one to understand this meaning. Now, taking advantage of the opportunity provided by the meaning, one should further contemplate.
How are the atoms of the eyes and other faculties arranged?

Because their differences cannot be seen, although it is difficult to establish them, since they are resistant, abide in space, and are born from a combination, one must definitely explain their differences in arrangement.

The atoms of the eye faculty reside on the eye's crystalline lens, facing their own objects and abiding side by side, like the clear petals of a flower. A clear membrane covers them, preventing their dispersal.

Some say they reside like a ball, one on top of the other, because their substance is clear, like an autumn pond, not obstructing each other.ğŸ”½The atoms of the ear faculty reside in the ear holes, spiraling and abiding, like curled birch bark.
The atoms of the nose faculty reside inside the nostrils, facing the back and below, like a pair of fingernails.
The first three faculties, in terms of their horizontal extent, have no height or depth, like a garland of flowers worn on the head.
The atoms of the tongue sense base are distributed on the tongue, shaped like a half-moon, about the size of a hair tip, not completely covering the tongue.
The atoms of the body sense base are distributed over the parts of the body, the same size as the body.
The atoms of the female organ are shaped like a drum, the atoms of the male organ are shaped like a finger.

Sometimes all the atoms of the eye sense base are of the same kind, sometimes all are of a different kind, sometimes one part is of a different kind and the rest are of the same kind. The atoms of the tongue sense base are also like this.

The atoms of the body sense base definitely do not all belong to the same kind, even in the extremely hot hells where fierce flames wrap around the body, there are still innumerable atoms of the body sense base that are of a different kind.

Therefore it is said that if one generates consciousness everywhere, the body should be scattered and destroyed, because there is no single atom of the sense base or object that can serve as the support or object and generate body consciousness.
The five consciousnesses definitely accumulate many subtle [forms] to form their support, because they are by nature objects.
How are the supports of the six consciousnesses established?

Are the supports of the various consciousnesses also like this, with the five consciousnesses only taking the present as objects and mental consciousness taking the three times and non-time as objects?
No, it is not so.
How is it?
The verse says:
The later support is only past, the support of the five may be simultaneous.
The treatise says:
After the six consciousnesses cease, they are all called mental consciousness. This serves as the support for mental consciousness. Therefore, mental consciousness only relies on past eyes, etc.

The support of the five consciousnesses may be simultaneous or past. The word or indicates that this also relies on the past. The five such as eyes are the simultaneous supports. The past support is precisely the mental consciousness element.
Thus, the supports of the five consciousnesses are each two. The support of the sixth mental consciousness is only one.
In order to clarify the differences in meaning of the supports in the verse, it should be further asked:
If it is the nature that is the support of eye consciousness, is it also the similar and immediately antecedent condition of eye consciousness?
If it is the similar and immediately antecedent condition of eye consciousness, is it also the nature that is the support of eye consciousness?
Four sentences should be made.
The first sentence is the eye faculty that arises together [with eye consciousness].
The second sentence is the mental factor realm that has just ceased.
The third sentence is the mind faculty of the past.
The fourth sentence is excluding what was explained above.
Up to body consciousness, it is also like this.
Each should explain its own faculty. The answer for mental consciousness should be made in accordance with the first sentence.
That which is the nature that is the support of mental consciousness is definitely the similar and immediately antecedent condition of mental consciousness.

There is that which is the similar and immediately antecedent condition of mental consciousness, but is not the nature that is the support of mental consciousness, namely the mental factor realm that has just ceased.
Moreover, the five consciousness realms are definitely past or present, like their supporting faculties. Are their objects also like this, or are there differences?
There are differences in samÄdhi.
That which has already ceased and that which has not yet arisen are not the objects of the five consciousnesses.
Why is this?
Because they arise together with the support and one object, and because the support does not arise with respect to non-present objects.
The sÅ«tras say:
Dependent on the eye and forms, eye-consciousness arises. And so on at length.
For what reason does the arising of consciousness depend on two conditions and obtain the name of support?
It is in the root, not in the object.
The verse says:
Consciousness changes according to the change in the root, therefore the eye, etc. are called the support.
The commentary says:
The eye, etc. are the six elements of the eye, etc. Because the eye, etc. change,
the changes in consciousness follow the increase and decrease of the root, because there is clarity and obscurity.
Forms, etc. do not change and cause consciousness to be different, because consciousness follows the root and not the object.
The name support is only in the eye, etc. and not in the others.

If this is so, then the mental consciousness also changes with the body, because when the body is harmed by wind or bile, the mental consciousness is disturbed, but when the body is at rest, the mental consciousness is clear.
Why is it that the mental consciousness is not based on the body?
There is no error, because it follows its own support.
When the body is harmed by wind or bile, a body consciousness arises that is associated with the feeling of pain. This body consciousness is called a disturbed mental element.
When this body consciousness, together with the feeling of pain, ceases, it can give rise to a disturbed mental consciousness as its support.
When it is the opposite of this, the mental consciousness is clear. Therefore, the mental consciousness follows its own support.
The phrase â€œfollows its own supportâ€ shows that it follows the differences in the clarity and obscurity of the support, and does not show that it is good or indeterminate.
Why is it that what is perceived is the object and not the faculty, yet the name of consciousness is established according to the faculty?
It is because it follows the faculty and not the object.
A verse says:
Because it is the cause of that and of the unique [faculty], consciousness is said to follow the faculty.
The treatise says:
The YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra says, The so-called eye consciousness is called consciousness because it is named according to its support, not according to its object.
This is because the support is superior to the object.
The word exclusive means that the eye is the support only of visual consciousness and not of other consciousnesses.

Form is grasped by visual consciousness of the same person and also by visual consciousness of another person, and also by mental consciousness of the same person and also of another person. This is also true of the other organs up to and including the body.
Why not call it dharma consciousness, because its object is not exclusive?
This objection is unreasonable, because the general term dharma is not exclusive, and the specific term dharma realm does not include consciousness.
That is, the general term dharma is not only not exclusive, but the specific term dharma realm does not include consciousness.
Also, although the specific dharma realm is not common to other consciousnesses, it is not the nature of the support of mental consciousness.
Therefore, if a dharma is the support of consciousness and is exclusive, then consciousness is named according to it.
This is not the case with form, etc., and therefore consciousness is not named according to them, just as one speaks of the sound of a drum or the sprout of wheat.
The verse also has another meaning: because the eye and so on are the basis of consciousness.
And because they are unique.

There is one person who produces four kinds of eye consciousnesses, but there is no one kind of eye faculty that produces two kinds of eye consciousnesses, let alone one that can produce four kinds of consciousnesses.
In this way, consciousness is produced separately by the different realms, destinies, species, bodies, and eyes. Therefore, it is called unique. The same applies to the body.
Isn't it that the mental faculty of another person also produces [consciousness]?
Consciousness produced by the mental faculty of another life is not completely unproduced, but it is not simultaneous.

There is no one kind of mental faculty that simultaneously produces two kinds of mental consciousnesses of different lives, which can be like form and so on. Therefore, it is said that there are not two, let alone four.
In this way, because it is the basis of consciousness, it produces consciousness separately according to the realms, destinies, and so on.
For these two reasons, it follows the faculty, not the object.
When the eye sees form while the body is dwelling in a certain place, are the body, eye, form, and consciousness in the same realm?
It should be said that these four may be different or the same.
What is meant by the same? It means that when born in the desire realm, using eyes of one's own realm to see forms of one's own realm, all four are of the same realm.

When born in the first dhyÄna, using eyes of one's own realm to see forms of one's own realm, they are also all of the same realm. When born in other realms, there is no case of all four being the same.ğŸ”½What is meant by different? It means that when born in the desire realm, if using eyes of the first dhyÄna to see forms of the desire realm, the body and forms belong to the desire realm, while the eye consciousness belongs to the first dhyÄna. When seeing forms of the first dhyÄna, the body belongs to the desire realm, while the three [eye, form, and consciousness] belong to the first dhyÄna.ğŸ”½If using eyes of the second dhyÄna to see forms of the desire realm, the body and forms belong to the desire realm, while the eyes belong to the second dhyÄna, and the consciousness belongs to the first dhyÄna. When seeing forms of the first dhyÄna, the body belongs to the desire realm, while the eyes belong to the second dhyÄna.

The forms and consciousness belong to the first dhyÄna. When seeing forms of the second dhyÄna, the body belongs to the desire realm, while the eyes and forms belong to the second dhyÄna, and the consciousness belongs to the first dhyÄna.
If one uses the eyes of the third or fourth dhyÄna stages to see forms of lower stages or of one's own stage, you should understand this in accordance with reason.
If one is born in the four dhyÄna stages, there are differences in the four matters. You should consider this in accordance with reason.
The other sense bases should also be discriminated in this way.
We will now briefly explain the definitive characteristics of these.
A verse says:
The eyes are not lower than the body, and form and eye consciousness are not higher than the eyes.
Form is in all consciousnesses, and the two are also so in relation to the body.
The ears are also like this. The next three are all of their own stage.
Body consciousness is of its own stage or lower. Mental consciousness should be understood as indefinite.
The treatise says:
The body, eyes, and form are all in five stages, namely the desire realm and the four dhyÄnas.
Eye consciousness is only in the desire realm and the first dhyÄna.
Here, the eye faculty is either equal to or higher than the body in the stage where it is born, and never lower.
Form and eye consciousness are either equal to or lower than the eyes, but not higher.
The eye faculty of a lower stage is accustomed to seeing gross form, and has no power to see subtle form of a higher stage.
Also, the eye faculty of a lower stage has no superior function.
The higher stages have their own superior eye faculty, and in the lower stages there is eye consciousness. Therefore, the eye faculty of a lower stage is not the support of a higher consciousness.
Form is related to consciousness, and is either equal, higher, or lower.
Form and consciousness are related to the body in the same way that form is related to consciousness. This means that they are either of the same stage, or higher or lower.

Consciousness is related to the body, and is of the same stage only when one is born in the desire realm or the first trance state. If it is of a higher stage, it is only when one is born in the desire realm. If it is of a lower stage, it is only when one is born in the second, third, or fourth trance states.
Form is related to the body, and is of the same or lower stage when one sees with the eyes of a higher stage. If it is of a higher stage, it is only when one sees with the eyes of a higher stage.
If one uses the eye faculty of one's own stage, one only sees form of the same or lower stage.
If one uses the eye faculty of a higher stage, one sees form of one's own stage or a lower stage.

The extensive explanation of the ear should be understood as like that of the eye. That is, the ear is not below the body, sound, or ear consciousness, but above the ear and sound in relation to consciousness, and in all cases two of the three are so related.
The same is so for the body. The extensive explanation should be understood as in the case of the eye, according to circumstances.
The three of nose, tongue, and body are all in the same realm as their corresponding consciousnesses, because their objects are mostly the same.
Because the two of smell and taste are only in the realm of desire, and because the nose and tongue only take objects that reach them.
The difference among them is that the body and its object, touch, are in the same realm, because they take objects that reach them.
Consciousness in relation to touch and the body may be the same or lower.
The same means that if one is born in the realm of desire or the first trance state, if born in the upper three trance states, it is called lower.

You should understand that the mental faculty is not fixed in the four matters, that is, sometimes the mental faculty is in the same realm as the body, consciousness, and dharmas, and sometimes it is above or below.
The body is only in five stages, and the three are in all stages. One is only born in five stages.
When oneâ€™s own mental faculty, oneâ€™s own consciousness, and dharmas of oneâ€™s own stage are called the mental faculty, the three are in the same stage.

Sometimes the mental faculty belongs to a higher stage, when one is engaged in meditation or is born in the realm of desire and the mental faculty belongs to a higher stage, while the other three belong to a lower stage.

Or, when one is born in the first trance state, etc., and the consciousness of the first two or three trance states, etc., is produced immediately after the second or third trance state, etc., and the mental faculty belongs to a higher stage, while the other three belong to a lower stage.
In this way, if one is born in the first trance state, etc., and produces a lower stage immediately after a higher stage, one should understand it in accordance with the principle.

At the time of rebirth, there is no mental faculty of a higher stage. It is definitely not the case that the body faculty of a lower stage is not extinguished and one receives rebirth in a higher stage.
Also, there is no one who, while abiding in a different stage of mind, ends his life.
In this way, one should understand that there is no mental faculty of a lower stage that depends on a body of a higher stage.

If the body is in a lower stage, the mind is in a higher stage, and the mind experiences the body, this is not contrary to reason. That is, when one first unites with the desire or form realms after emerging from a higher stage, the mind belongs to the higher stage, but the body consciousness belongs to the lower stage.
The dharmas that it experiences may belong to its own stage, to a higher stage, or to the formless realm.
You should understand that if the body is in a higher stage, the mind is in a lower stage, and the mind experiences the body, this is also not contrary to reason.

When one is in samÄdhi, if the mind is in a lower stage and the body is in a higher stage, this is also not contrary to reason. That is, if one is born in a higher stage, one first produces the body consciousness and transformation mind of a lower stage.
The same is true of the dharmas of consciousness.

We must also consider the following question: If the eye of the desire realm sees forms of the desire realm, or if the eye of the form realm sees forms of the two realms, at that time, how many kinds of visual consciousnesses are there that can cognize those forms?
How many kinds of discrimination are produced in regard to them?
In order to avoid confusion in regard to our own doctrines, we will first make a general analysis and then later give a detailed explanation.
You should understand that the above discussion of imagination and uncertainty is only a part of the total picture, because memory and discrimination are found in all stages.
On the basis of these two kinds of discrimination, all visual consciousnesses are nondiscriminative.
Also, good discrimination can take as objects all stages, higher and lower. Defiled discrimination takes as objects the higher stages. Indeterminate discrimination takes as objects the lower stages.
In the stage in which one is born, one possesses all three kinds of discrimination of that stage, because one has not yet eliminated craving for that stage.
If one has eliminated craving for that stage, one possesses only two kinds of discrimination of that stage, excluding the defiled. One does not generate discrimination of other stages.
When a good visual consciousness of the first trance state is present, it is definitely bound to the stage in which it is born.

One born in the first trance state cannot generate a good visual consciousness based on the eye organ of another stage. One born in another stage cannot generate a nondiscriminated, indeterminate discrimination of another stage, because it is also definitely bound to the stage in which it is born.

It is not the intention of this treatise to speak only of discrimination produced in one lifetime, because if it were said that one lifetime is without discrimination, then one born in a higher stage would certainly be without discrimination in a lower stage.
And it is impossible for the three kinds of discrimination to occur in the present in this lifetime.
Also, discrimination in a higher stage would be only good and not indeterminate, because the reason has already been given above.
It is said in general that all exist in other lifetimes.

Having generally distinguished them, we must now explain them separately.ğŸ”½When one who has severed the good roots sees form with the eye, that form is discriminated by the defiled, non-obscuring, indeterminate eye consciousness, and he again produces three kinds of discrimination with regard to it, namely good, defiled, and non-obscuring, indeterminate.

When one who has not severed the good roots but is not yet free from craving sees form with the eye, that form is discriminated by the three kinds of eye consciousness, and he again produces three kinds of discrimination with regard to it.

If ordinary beings are born in the desire realm, have already abandoned desire for the desire realm but have not yet abandoned desire for the first concentration, when they use eyes of the desire realm to see forms, these forms are cognized by wholesome and unobscured indeterminate eye consciousness, and they also give rise to desire realm discrimination with regard to them.
If they are of the type that can retrogress, they possess all three types. If they are of the type that cannot retrogress, they only have two types, excluding the defiled one.

When using eyes of the first concentration to see forms of the desire realm, these forms are only cognized by unobscured indeterminate eye consciousness, and they also give rise to desire realm discrimination with regard to them, as should be understood as before.
They also give rise to two types of discrimination belonging to the first concentration, excluding the defiled one.

When using eyes of the first concentration to see forms of that realm, these forms are only cognized by unobscured indeterminate eye consciousness, and they also give rise to desire realm discrimination. If they are of the type that can retrogress, there are two types, excluding the unobscured one.
If they are of the type that cannot retrogress, there is only the wholesome one.

Furthermore, the first trance state gives rise to three kinds of discrimination. One who has already abandoned craving for the first trance state but has not yet abandoned craving for the second trance state, when using the eyes of the second trance state to see forms of the desire realm, these forms are only cognized by the eye consciousness of the desire realm, which is unobstructed and indeterminate. Furthermore, it gives rise to discrimination of the desire realm. If one is of the type that can retrogress, one has all three kinds. If one is of the type that cannot retrogress, one only has two kinds, namely excluding the defiled one.

Furthermore, it gives rise to discrimination of the first trance state. If one is of the type that can retrogress, one has two kinds, namely excluding the defiled one. If one is of the type that cannot retrogress, one only has the wholesome one.
Furthermore, it gives rise to two kinds of discrimination of the second trance state, namely excluding the defiled one.

When using the eyes of the second trance state to see forms of the first trance state, these forms are only cognized by the eye consciousness of the first trance state, which is unobstructed and indeterminate. Furthermore, it gives rise to discrimination of the desire realm. If one is of the type that can retrogress, one has two kinds, namely excluding the unobstructed and indeterminate one. If one is of the type that cannot retrogress, it is only the wholesome one.

Furthermore, the first trance state gives rise to discrimination, and if one is of the class that regresses, one possesses all three kinds, but if one is of the class that does not regress, then it is only good.
Furthermore, the three stages of trance give rise to two kinds of discrimination, excluding the defiled.

When the eye of the second trance state sees form of the third trance state, this form is only discriminated by the eye consciousness that is neither-retribution-nor-universal, and furthermore, it gives rise to discrimination of the desire realm, and if one is of the class that regresses, then there are two kinds, excluding that which is neither-retribution-nor-universal, and if one is of the class that does not regress, then it is only good.
It should be understood that the first trance state that gives rise to discrimination is also like this.

Furthermore, the three stages of trance give rise to three kinds of discrimination, following the principle of the specific explanations given above. Those who have already eliminated craving for the second trance state but have not yet eliminated craving for the third trance state, those who have already eliminated craving for the third trance state but have not yet eliminated craving for the fourth trance state, and those who have already eliminated craving for the fourth trance state, should all contemplate in accordance with the principle, examining each one.

It is said that ordinary beings are born in the desire realm, and likewise are born in the four meditations, and that noble ones are born in the five stages, and this should be explained in detail according to their respective cases.

However, there is a difference, namely that noble ones, whether retrogressing or not retrogressing, all have no defiled discrimination of higher stages, because the universal [contaminants] of different stages have all been eliminated, and because the merits of the path of seeing are definitely not subject to retrogressing.
By this method, one should infer and investigate further.
The consciousness and discrimination of hearing sounds, etc., and the subsidiary discussions are now complete. The main discussion should be clarified.

Now we should contemplate: Among the eighteen realms, which are cognized by which of the six consciousnesses? How many are cognized by how many consciousnesses? How many are permanent and how many are impermanent? How many are faculties and how many are not faculties?
The verse says:
The five external [realms] are cognized by two [consciousnesses], the permanent dharmadhÄtu is unconditioned,
One part of the dharmas is a faculty, and also the twelve internal realms.
The treatise says:
Among the eighteen elements, the five elements of form, etc., are cognized by the five consciousnesses of the eye, etc., respectively, and are also cognized by mental consciousness.
Thus these five elements are cognized by two consciousnesses among the six consciousnesses.
By this principle, the remaining thirteen elements are cognized only by mental consciousness, because they are not objects of the five consciousnesses.

There is not a single element that is entirely permanent among the eighteen elements. Only one part of the element of dharmas, namely the unconditioned dharmas, are permanent. By implication, the remaining dharmas and the other elements are impermanent.
Among the eighteen elements, one part of the element of dharmas and the twelve internal ones are faculties, not the others. The five faculties of sensation,
the five faculties such as faith, and the life faculty in their entirety, and three parts of the three pure faculties are categorized as the element of dharmas.
The five faculties such as the eye are categorized as such by their own names. The female and male faculties are categorized as parts of the body element, as will be explained later.
The faculty of thought is included in the seven mental sense bases. The last three are included in the mental faculty and mental consciousness.
By implication, the remaining five sense bases such as form, and part of the sense base of dharmas, are all not faculties.
